<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/"/>

<meta property="og:author" content="Nathaniel Quist"/>

<meta name="post_tags" content="API attacks,Containers,IAM,serverless"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Cloud Threats on the Rise: Alert Trends Show Intensified Attacker Focus on IAM, Exfiltration","name":"Cloud Threats on the Rise: Alert Trends Show Intensified Attacker Focus on IAM, Exfiltration","description":"Understanding trends amidst noise: tracking shifts in security alerts allows cloud defenders to parse threats from attackers targeting IAM, storage and more.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/2025-cloud-security-alert-trends\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/2025-cloud-security-alert-trends\/","datePublished":"March 27, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nThe attacks against cloud-hosted infrastructure are increasing, and the proof is in the analysis of security alert trends. Recent research reveals that organizations saw nearly five times as many daily cloud-based alerts at the end of 2024 compared to the start of the year. This means attackers have significantly intensified their focus on targeting and breaching cloud infrastructure.\r\n\r\nThese alerts aren\u2019t simply noise. We\u2019ve seen the greatest increases in high severity alerts, meaning indicators of attacks are successfully targeting critical cloud resources as explained in Table 1.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCloud Resource\r\nWhy It\u2019s Critical\r\n\r\n\r\nIdentity and access management (IAM)\r\nLeaked credentials can open the door to an organization\u2019s cloud infrastructure.\r\n\r\n\r\nStorage\r\nCan contain sensitive organizational or customer data.\r\n\r\n\r\nVirtual machines\r\nOften connected to additional internal services, offering lateral movement opportunities to attackers.\r\n\r\n\r\nContainers\r\nContainer host exploitation can allow attackers to run malicious containers.\r\n\r\n\r\nServerless\r\nServerless functions are designed for singular automated purposes. Remote command line executions should not occur.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. Criticality of certain cloud resources.\r\n\r\nOf particular note, attackers frequently targeted serverless IAM tokens resulting in remote command-line usage. These are significant because they can be used to gain access to an organization\u2019s larger cloud environment. As part of the increase of cloud alerts, there were three times as many remote command-line access events utilizing identity access and management (IAM) tokens, and credentials that are used by cloud serverless functions.\r\n\r\nWe also identified other upward trends in alerting:\r\n\r\n \tAn 116% increase in IAM-based \u201cimpossible travel event\u201d alerts (i.e., login events from distant geographic areas within a narrow time window)\r\n \tA 60% increase in IAM application programming interface (API) requests from outside regions for compute resources (cloud virtual machine)\r\n \tA peak 45% increase in the number of cloud snapshot exports during November 2024\r\n \tA 305% increase in the number of suspicious downloads of multiple cloud storage objects\r\n\r\nIdentity is the defense perimeter of cloud infrastructure. Attackers target IAM tokens and credentials as they hold the keys to the cloud kingdom, allowing attackers to move laterally, escalate their permissions and perform additional malicious operations. The rise in the number of access attempts and usage of sensitive IAM service accounts means attackers across the globe have their sites set on cloud resources.\r\n\r\nAttackers target cloud storage services as they often contain sensitive data. We saw a notable increase in the number of suspicious cloud storage object downloads and image snapshot exports. Suspicious cloud storage object download alerts trigger when a single IAM-based identity downloads a large number of storage objects within a narrow time window. This can signify malicious operations such as ransomware or extortion. Image snapshots are targeted by attackers as snapshots can contain sensitive data regarding cloud infrastructure and IAM credentials that could allow the attacker to escalate permissions and move laterally within a victim cloud environment.\r\n\r\nThese examples illustrate the immediate need to protect cloud environments, not solely with foundational cloud security posture management (CSPM) tools, but in cooperation with tools that detect and prevent malicious runtime operations as they occur.\r\n\r\nBy deploying Cortex Cloud\u2019s runtime cloud security tooling \u2014 also called Cloud Detection and Response (CDR) \u2014 security teams can identify and prevent malicious events within cloud environments.\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nCloud Cybersecurity Research\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCloud Attacks at Scale\r\nIn a recent Unit 42 post, we published details of a ransomware and extortion campaign that directly targeted exposed environment variable files. The campaign\u2019s threat actor successfully harvested over 90,000 credentials from 110,000 targeted domains. More worryingly, they also harvested nearly 1,200 cloud IAM credentials. These credentials allowed the threat actor to successfully perform extortion attacks against multiple organizations.\r\n\r\nThis operation highlights an opportunity to discuss the security mechanisms that are in place to protect organizations. Specifically, this allows us to determine how to employ both posture management and runtime monitoring security solutions seamlessly. This allows organizations to build a cloud security defense perimeter that is sufficiently robust, and capable of facing these new waves of attackers.\r\n\r\nDuring the investigation for this article, we discovered that the average total number of cloud alerts experienced by an organization increased by 388% in 2024. These alerts originated from both posture management and runtime monitoring detection operations.\r\n\r\nAlthough alerts with \u201cinformational\u201d severity did account for the majority of alerts, it is extremely important to highlight that the most significant change was in the number of high severity alerts. This classification of alert saw an increase of 235% during 2024. Medium and low severity alerts also increased by 21% and 10%, respectively.\r\nWhat These Trending Alerts Signify\r\nThe changes we observed in the number of alerts align with our 2024 State of Cloud-Native Security Report, which found that 71% of organizations attribute increased vulnerability exposures to accelerated deployments. Furthermore, 45% of those organizations report a rise in advanced persistent threat (APT) attacks over the last year.\r\n\r\nA case in point is Microsoft\u2019s recent research on Storm-2077, a China-based cloud threat actor group (CTAG) that employs complex cloud IAM credential harvesting techniques to obtain and to maintain access to victim cloud environments. It quickly becomes apparent that both cloud posture management and runtime security monitoring must function as a single unit to perform adequate protection from the next phase of threats in cloud environments. The Background section below provides additional information on posture management and runtime monitoring detections.\r\n\r\nA key mission for cloud defenders is to design and deploy a cloud security platform that will improve detection capabilities. This allows administrators not only to detect misconfigurations and vulnerabilities, but also to collect and analyze the runtime events within cloud environments. Such a platform provides defenders with better visibility and enables quicker response time when dealing with alerts.\r\n\r\nWhile the ability to identify and detect malicious or suspicious cloud events has increased across the industry, so has the complexity of threat actors\u2019 offensive cloud operations. For example, in January 2024, the average cloud environment saw only two alerts for the remote command-line usage of a serverless function IAM token. This stayed consistent throughout the year. However, by December 2024, the average cloud environment saw more than 200 of those same alerts \u2013 a worrying signal of increased activity. As shared in the Leaked Environment Variables article, this runtime operation is exactly what occurred during that malicious extortion event.\r\n\r\nFurther evidence supporting this trend includes the following:\r\n\r\n \tAn 116% rise in impossible travel alerts relating to cloud identities\r\n \tA 60% increase in the number of compute workload API calls occurring from outside of that instance\u2019s cloud region\r\n \tA 45% increase in the number cloud snapshot exports\r\n \tA 305% increase in the number of suspicious downloads of multiple cloud storage objects\r\n\r\nBoth of these alert findings strongly indicate that the prime objective of CTAGs is targeting, collecting and using a cloud IAM token or credential. This also indicates that attackers will use these tokens or credentials for potentially malicious operations.\r\nBackground\r\nCloud security posture management (CSPM) tools form the foundation of cloud security. Their operations center on guardrail control monitoring to ensure that cloud environments maintain secure configurations and are free from vulnerabilities and misconfigurations.\r\n\r\nPosture management monitoring is traditionally based on time-specific security scanning of a cloud environment\u2019s resources and configurations. Alerts are triggered when a new or modified cloud resource appears to pose potential security risks.\r\n\r\nFor example, an alert will be triggered if an IAM policy is overly permissive and allows access to other cloud resources. It will also be triggered if a cloud compute instance or serverless function contains vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.\r\n\r\nPosture management scanning operations are performed on a routine schedule, often hourly or daily. Some CSPM security tools allow for the monitoring of cloud platform auditing logs as well, which can assist in detecting suspicious activity as it occurs within a cloud service platform (CSP). It is critical that organizations configure their CSPM platform to collect the audit logs from their third-party cloud-based software-as-a-service (SaaS) applications to ensure visibility.\r\n\r\nCDR tools provide runtime monitoring detections by collecting, identifying and even preventing operations that occur during a particular event. By collecting the logs from cloud compute instances, CSP logging resources and third-party cloud SaaS applications, CDR security tools can identify, alert on and prevent malicious cloud events.\r\n\r\nExamples of these operations include the execution of an API request against a cloud platform or cloud application such as:\r\n\r\n \tCreating new cloud users or service accounts\r\n \tAttaching IAM policies to new or established IAM users or roles\r\n \tEstablishing network connections from a Tor exit node or VPN host\r\n\r\nIn contrast to posture management tools, runtime monitoring tools continuously monitor the cloud environment and often require a dedicated agent to maintain visibility of the cloud resources. When an agent is installed, cloud runtime monitoring security tools allow for the detection \u2014 and even prevention \u2014 of malicious cloud operations as they occur.\r\nHigh Severity Alert Trends\r\nWe have observed a clear increase in the number of alerts in 2024, correlating with the rise in attacks on cloud environments.\r\n\r\nHigh severity cloud alerts increased by 235% throughout 2024. The largest single-month spike (281%) occurred in May, and we noted the most substantial increase in these alerts (204%, 247% and 122%) in August, October and December, as shown in Figure 1.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_138751\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 1. High severity alert trends for 2024.[\/caption]\r\nTop 10 High Alerts\r\nA closer look at the top 10 most frequent daily high severity alerts reveals a high number of alerts pertaining solely to runtime-focused events. These alerts are triggered by a singular event or a sequence of connected events. This necessitated near real-time analysis or, in some instances, real-time analysis for detection.\r\n\r\nTable 2 below shows that the remote command-line usage of the serverless IAM tokens is an event that requires real-time log analysis to detect and potentially to prevent. Conversely, the most frequent high severity alert, \u201ccloud storage delete protection disabled,\u201d can be detected and mitigated with a CSPM tool.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAlert Name\r\nRuntime or Posture Control\r\nAverage Daily Count\r\n\r\n\r\nRemote command line usage of serverless token\r\nRuntime\r\n24.68\r\n\r\n\r\nAn identity performed a suspicious download of multiple cloud storage objects\r\nRuntime\r\n21.09\r\n\r\n\r\nCloud Storage Delete Protection Disabled\r\nPosture and Runtime\r\n20.19\r\n\r\n\r\nAbnormal Allocation of compute resources in a high number of regions\r\nPosture and Runtime\r\n11.11\r\n\r\n\r\nA Kubernetes node service account was used outside the cluster from non-cloud IP\r\nPosture\r\n11\r\n\r\n\r\nAbnormal Suspicious allocation of compute resources in multiple regions\r\nPosture and Runtime\r\n10\r\n\r\n\r\nMultiple cloud snapshots export\r\nRuntime\r\n9.33\r\n\r\n\r\nRemote command line usage of serverless role\r\nRuntime\r\n7.79\r\n\r\n\r\nUnusual allocation of multiple cloud compute resources\r\nPosture and Runtime\r\n7.73\r\n\r\n\r\nAbnormal Unusual allocation of compute resources in multiple regions\r\nPosture and Runtime\r\n6.42\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 2. High severity alerting by average occurrence.\r\n\r\nTo ensure the protection of cloud storage objects within a storage container whose delete protection has been disabled, we highly recommend deploying a CDR tool. These tools can detect and prevent any cloud storage objects from being deleted as a result of a \u201dprotection disabled\u201d event.\r\n\r\nOther notable high severity alerts include multiple cloud snapshot exports and suspicious usage of a service account IAM. Both of these are key indicators of malicious activity within a cloud environment.\r\n\r\nExamples of malicious operations that could trigger several of these alerts are cloud-focused extortion or ransomware events. These types of events can only be leveraged by first disabling cloud storage protections, such as delete protection and automatic backups. Once these protections are removed, malicious actors can delete or exfiltrate cloud storage container objects, increasing the likelihood of a successful extortion operation.\r\n\r\nSome of these high severity alerts could also be triggered by the compromise of exposed or vulnerable serverless or compute instance resources. Specifically in terms of the remote command-line usage of a serverless IAM token, serverless functions are designed to operate autonomously and independently.\r\n\r\nRemote or unauthorized usage of a serverless function's IAM token indicates compromise and potential lateral movement within the cloud environment. The same type of event could indicate the malicious usage of a service account IAM token. Given that service account IAM tokens are typically intended for a single purpose, any abnormal usage of that token should be considered suspicious.\r\nMedium Severity Alert Trends\r\nUnlike the end-of-year high severity alert spike, we saw a sustained spike in medium severity alerts mid-2024. This spike included an initial 186% and subsequent 24% increase, before a downward trend through December, as Figure 2 shows.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_138762\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. Medium severity alert trends for 2024.[\/caption]\r\nTop 10 Medium Alerts\r\nThe top 10 medium severity alerts, shown in Table 3 below, differ from the top 10 high severity alerts listed in Table 2 above. The key difference is that for all but one of the top 10 medium severity alerts, the events can only be detected by performing some form of runtime protection analytics.\r\n\r\nThe \u201cunusual high-volume data transfer\u201d event can be triggered using traditional CSPM detections of cloud resources. However, like the high severity \u201ccloud storage delete protection disabled\u201d event discussed above, a CDR tool would be better able to detect this unusual volume transfer event as it was occurring. It could also identify the types of files and their cloud storage file or directory locations. These details provide security teams with the most desired resources to perform their jobs: time, and knowledge.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAlert Name\r\nRuntime or Posture Control\r\nAverage Daily Count\r\n\r\n\r\nAn IAM identity attempted multiple actions on resources that were denied\r\nRuntime\r\n80\r\n\r\n\r\nA compute-attached identity executed API calls outside the instance's region\r\nRuntime\r\n36.32\r\n\r\n\r\nAttempted cloud application access from unusual tenant\r\nRuntime\r\n21.69\r\n\r\n\r\nAn identity performed a suspicious download of multiple cloud storage objects from multiple buckets\r\nRuntime\r\n18.66\r\n\r\n\r\nImpossible travel by a cloud compute identity\r\nRuntime\r\n18.65\r\n\r\n\r\nUnusual storage high-volume data transfer\r\nRuntime\r\n15\r\n\r\n\r\nKubernetes service account activity outside the cluster from non-cloud IP\r\nRuntime\r\n12.15\r\n\r\n\r\nA cloud application performed multiple actions that were denied\r\nRuntime\r\n12.02\r\n\r\n\r\nMultiple cloud snapshots export\r\nRuntime\r\n10\r\n\r\n\r\nSuspicious identity downloaded multiple objects from a backup storage bucket\r\nRuntime\r\n9.68\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 3. Medium severity alerting by average occurrence.\r\n\r\nSeveral of the alerts listed in Table 3 could indicate that malicious actors are targeting cloud resources such as Kubernetes service accounts outside of the cluster or from a non-cloud IP address. These two alerts in particular might indicate that the Kubernetes cluster authentication tokens have been compromised, as service account IAM tokens are designed for a singular purpose. Any operation using these credentials from outside of the cluster \u2014 or outside of the known cloud environment \u2014 should be considered suspicious activity and should be mitigated.\r\n\r\nAnother alert that is important to highlight is exporting multiple cloud snapshots. While there can be a legitimate use case for this type of event \u2014 such as th\u200b\u200be deployment of snapshots or an external backup \u2014 threat actors also export snapshots. Cloud snapshots can contain sensitive information, making them a common target of malicious operations.\r\nWhat Organizations Can Do\r\nThere are several steps that organizations can implement to better protect themselves against malicious cloud operations:\r\n\r\n \tImplement effective CDR runtime monitoring\r\n\r\n \tDeploy a CDR cloud security for all of your cloud environments\r\n \tEnsure that all mission-critical cloud endpoints have runtime enabled agents to detect compute and container runtime operations\r\n \tEnsure runtime cloud audit log monitoring is available from your CSP providers\r\n \tEnsure that your integrated cloud SaaS applications collect:\r\n\r\n \tIdentity providers (IdP)\r\n \tCI\/CD integrations\r\n \tSource code repositories\r\n \tTicketing platforms\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \tPlace limits on CSP regions in which compute and serverless functions are allowed to operate\r\n\r\n \tIt is common practice for threat actors to create cloud resources within foreign CSP regions to perform a basic form of operation obfuscation\r\n\r\n\r\n \tIdentify and prevent IAM service accounts from performing operations outside of their intended functions\r\n\r\n \tFollowing least-privilege architecture design for IAM credentials can greatly assist in combating lateral movement and privilege escalation operations if an IAM credential is compromised\r\n\r\n\r\n \tEnsure that cloud storage versioning and encryption are in place for all cloud storage containers\r\n\r\n \tVersioning and encryption are free configurations for every cloud storage container from each of the three major cloud service providers\r\n \tThese two features also significantly increase the difficulties that threat actors will encounter when trying to steal your valuable, sensitive information\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIf in doubt, remember that CDR runtime monitoring defenses must be present to effectively combat the majority of threats faced by cloud environments.\r\nConclusion\r\nCDR runtime monitoring is a critical aspect of maintaining a secure-cloud, hybrid-cloud and multi-cloud environment. As the trending high and medium severity alert data discussed in this article demonstrate, there was a 388% increase in the average number of alerts that cloud environments witnessed during 2024.\r\n\r\nA significant number of these alerts are the direct result of the detection of runtime operations, which cannot be detected with posture management (CSPM) tools alone. CDR tools provide cloud runtime detection capabilities, enabling the detection of malicious events occurring on cloud compute instances, container hosts or serverless functions.\r\n\r\nGiven the increasing threats targeting cloud environments, the only real defense for these environments is to require cloud-based agents for publicly exposed and critical cloud endpoints, CSP audit logging and cloud third-party SaaS applications. Using a CDR analytics tool allows defenders to collect, detect and prevent the execution of malicious operations that can affect any of these resources. The combination of runtime monitoring, analysis and response for cloud resource event logging is essential to ensure that malicious operations are not allowed to function within cloud environments.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team, or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 00080005045107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nReferences\r\n\r\n \tLeaked Environment Variables Allow Large-Scale Extortion Operation in Cloud Environments \u2013 Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \t2024 State of Cloud Native Security Report \u2013 Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tMicrosoft shares latest intelligence on North Korean and Chinese threat actors at CYBERWARCON \u2013 Threat Intelligence blog, Microsoft\r\n \tWhat Is CSPM? | Cloud Security Posture Management Explained \u2013 Cyberpedia, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tWhat Is CDR (Cloud Detection and Response)? \u2013 Cyberpedia, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tDefinition of Identity and Access Management (IAM) \u2013 Gartner Information Technology Glossary\r\n","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2025\/03\/04_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Nathaniel Quist"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

    </head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-138739 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>
      </div>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none ml-auto mb-40 order-2">
        <button class="btn__search" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#search" aria-label="search"><i class="ui ui-1"></i></button>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>

</ul>  </div>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">
    
<section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/04_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
			              <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/" role="link" title="Cloud Cybersecurity Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:hero:breadcrumb:Cloud Cybersecurity Research">Cloud Cybersecurity Research</a></li> </ul>

              <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:hero:Cloud Cybersecurity Research"><span class="ab-title__pre">Cloud Cybersecurity Research</span></a>

					<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2F2025-cloud-security-alert-trends%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Facebook" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:share:facebook"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-fb-share.svg" alt="Facebook Icon"></a>

				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2F2025-cloud-security-alert-trends%2F&#038;title=Cloud%20Threats%20on%20the%20Rise:%20Alert%20Trends%20Show%20Intensified%20Attacker%20Focus%20on%20IAM,%20Exfiltration" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in LinkedIn" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:share:linkedin"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-linkedin-share.svg" alt="LinkedIn Icon"></a>

				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2F2025-cloud-security-alert-trends%2F&#038;text=Cloud%20Threats%20on%20the%20Rise:%20Alert%20Trends%20Show%20Intensified%20Attacker%20Focus%20on%20IAM,%20Exfiltration" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Twitter" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:share:twitter"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-twitter-share.svg" alt="Twitter Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2F2025-cloud-security-alert-trends%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>

					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=Cloud%20Threats%20on%20the%20Rise:%20Alert%20Trends%20Show%20Intensified%20Attacker%20Focus%20on%20IAM,%20Exfiltration%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2F2025-cloud-security-alert-trends%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-138739-_5hojk6ro0u4z"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>The attacks against cloud-hosted infrastructure are increasing, and the proof is in the analysis of security alert trends. Recent research reveals that organizations saw nearly five times as many daily cloud-based alerts at the end of 2024 compared to the start of the year. This means attackers have significantly intensified their focus on targeting and breaching cloud infrastructure.</p>
<p>These alerts aren’t simply noise. We’ve seen the greatest increases in high severity alerts, meaning indicators of attacks are successfully targeting critical cloud resources as explained in Table 1.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Cloud Resource</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Why It’s Critical</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Identity and access management (IAM)</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Leaked credentials can open the door to an organization’s cloud infrastructure.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Storage</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Can contain sensitive organizational or customer data.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Virtual machines</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Often connected to additional internal services, offering lateral movement opportunities to attackers.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Containers</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Container host exploitation can allow attackers to run malicious containers.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Serverless</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Serverless functions are designed for singular automated purposes. Remote command line executions should not occur.</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 1. Criticality of certain cloud resources.</span></p>
<p>Of particular note, attackers frequently targeted serverless IAM tokens resulting in remote command-line usage. These are significant because they can be used to gain access to an organization’s larger cloud environment. As part of the increase of cloud alerts, there were three times as many remote command-line access events utilizing identity access and management (IAM) tokens, and credentials that are used by cloud serverless functions.</p>
<p>We also identified other upward trends in alerting:</p>
<ul>
<li>An 116% increase in IAM-based “impossible travel event” alerts (i.e., login events from distant geographic areas within a narrow time window)</li>
<li>A 60% increase in IAM application programming interface (API) requests from outside regions for compute resources (cloud virtual machine)</li>
<li>A peak 45% increase in the number of cloud snapshot exports during November 2024</li>
<li>A 305% increase in the number of suspicious downloads of multiple cloud storage objects</li>
</ul>
<p>Identity is the defense perimeter of cloud infrastructure. Attackers target IAM tokens and credentials as they hold the keys to the cloud kingdom, allowing attackers to move laterally, escalate their permissions and perform additional malicious operations. The rise in the number of access attempts and usage of sensitive IAM service accounts means attackers across the globe have their sites set on cloud resources.</p>
<p>Attackers target cloud storage services as they often contain sensitive data. We saw a notable increase in the number of suspicious cloud storage object downloads and image snapshot exports. Suspicious cloud storage object download alerts trigger when a single IAM-based identity downloads a large number of storage objects within a narrow time window. This can signify malicious operations such as ransomware or extortion. Image snapshots are targeted by attackers as snapshots can contain sensitive data regarding cloud infrastructure and IAM credentials that could allow the attacker to escalate permissions and move laterally within a victim cloud environment.</p>
<p>These examples illustrate the immediate need to protect cloud environments, not solely with foundational cloud security posture management (CSPM) tools, but in cooperation with tools that detect and prevent malicious runtime operations as they occur.</p>
<p>By deploying Cortex Cloud’s runtime cloud security tooling — also called Cloud Detection and Response (<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-cloud-detection-and-response-cdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CDR</a>) — security teams can identify and prevent malicious events within cloud environments.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Cloud Cybersecurity Research</b></a></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-138739-_fbpbgj2gko8b"></a>Cloud Attacks at Scale</h2>
<p>In a <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/large-scale-cloud-extortion-operation/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">recent Unit 42 post</a>, we published details of a ransomware and extortion campaign that directly targeted exposed environment variable files. The campaign’s threat actor successfully harvested over 90,000 credentials from 110,000 targeted domains. More worryingly, they also harvested nearly 1,200 cloud IAM credentials. These credentials allowed the threat actor to successfully perform extortion attacks against multiple organizations.</p>
<p>This operation highlights an opportunity to discuss the security mechanisms that are in place to protect organizations. Specifically, this allows us to determine how to employ both posture management and runtime monitoring security solutions seamlessly. This allows organizations to build a cloud security defense perimeter that is sufficiently robust, and capable of facing these new waves of attackers.</p>
<p>During the investigation for this article, we discovered that the average total number of cloud alerts experienced by an organization increased by 388% in 2024. These alerts originated from both posture management and runtime monitoring detection operations.</p>
<p>Although alerts with “informational” severity did account for the majority of alerts, it is extremely important to highlight that the most significant change was in the number of high severity alerts. This classification of alert saw an increase of 235% during 2024. Medium and low severity alerts also increased by 21% and 10%, respectively.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138739-_k725hqxp6hz6"></a>What These Trending Alerts Signify</h3>
<p>The changes we observed in the number of alerts align with our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/state-of-cloud-native-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">2024 State of Cloud-Native Security Report,</a> which found that 71% of organizations attribute increased vulnerability exposures to accelerated deployments. Furthermore, 45% of those organizations report a rise in advanced persistent threat (APT) attacks over the last year.</p>
<p>A case in point is Microsoft’s recent research on <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2024/11/22/microsoft-shares-latest-intelligence-on-north-korean-and-chinese-threat-actors-at-cyberwarcon/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Storm-2077</a>, a China-based cloud threat actor group (CTAG) that employs complex cloud IAM credential harvesting techniques to obtain and to maintain access to victim cloud environments. It quickly becomes apparent that both cloud posture management and runtime security monitoring must function as a single unit to perform adequate protection from the next phase of threats in cloud environments. The <a href="#post-138739-_xlurxz18uhof">Background section</a> below provides additional information on posture management and runtime monitoring detections.</p>
<p>A key mission for cloud defenders is to design and deploy a cloud security platform that will improve detection capabilities. This allows administrators not only to detect misconfigurations and vulnerabilities, but also to collect and analyze the runtime events within cloud environments. Such a platform provides defenders with better visibility and enables quicker response time when dealing with alerts.</p>
<p>While the ability to identify and detect malicious or suspicious cloud events has increased across the industry, so has the complexity of threat actors’ offensive cloud operations. For example, in January 2024, the average cloud environment saw only two alerts for the remote command-line usage of a serverless function IAM token. This stayed consistent throughout the year. However, by December 2024, the average cloud environment saw more than 200 of those same alerts – a worrying signal of increased activity. As shared in the <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/large-scale-cloud-extortion-operation/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Leaked Environment Variables</a> article, this runtime operation is exactly what occurred during that malicious extortion event.</p>
<p>Further evidence supporting this trend includes the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>An 116% rise in impossible travel alerts relating to cloud identities</li>
<li>A 60% increase in the number of <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-workload" target="_blank" rel="noopener">compute workload</a> API calls occurring from outside of that instance’s cloud region</li>
<li>A 45% increase in the number cloud snapshot exports</li>
<li>A 305% increase in the number of suspicious downloads of multiple cloud storage objects</li>
</ul>
<p>Both of these alert findings strongly indicate that the prime objective of CTAGs is targeting, collecting and using a cloud IAM token or credential. This also indicates that attackers will use these tokens or credentials for potentially malicious operations.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138739-_xlurxz18uhof"></a>Background</h2>
<p>Cloud security posture management (<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-cloud-security-posture-management" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CSPM</a>) tools form the foundation of cloud security. Their operations center on guardrail control monitoring to ensure that cloud environments maintain secure configurations and are free from vulnerabilities and misconfigurations.</p>
<p>Posture management monitoring is traditionally based on time-specific security scanning of a cloud environment’s resources and configurations. Alerts are triggered when a new or modified cloud resource appears to pose potential security risks.</p>
<p>For example, an alert will be triggered if an IAM policy is overly permissive and allows access to other cloud resources. It will also be triggered if a cloud compute instance or serverless function contains vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.</p>
<p>Posture management scanning operations are performed on a routine schedule, often hourly or daily. Some CSPM security tools allow for the monitoring of cloud platform auditing logs as well, which can assist in detecting suspicious activity as it occurs within a cloud service platform (CSP). It is critical that organizations configure their CSPM platform to collect the audit logs from their third-party cloud-based software-as-a-service (SaaS) applications to ensure visibility.</p>
<p>CDR tools provide runtime monitoring detections by collecting, identifying and even preventing operations that occur during a particular event. By collecting the logs from cloud compute instances, CSP logging resources and third-party cloud SaaS applications, CDR security tools can identify, alert on and prevent malicious cloud events.</p>
<p>Examples of these operations include the execution of an API request against a cloud platform or cloud application such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Creating new cloud users or service accounts</li>
<li>Attaching IAM policies to new or established IAM users or roles</li>
<li>Establishing network connections from a Tor exit node or VPN host</li>
</ul>
<p>In contrast to posture management tools, runtime monitoring tools continuously monitor the cloud environment and often require a dedicated agent to maintain visibility of the cloud resources. When an agent is installed, cloud runtime monitoring security tools allow for the detection — and even prevention — of malicious cloud operations as they occur.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138739-_127rhugh6pkh"></a>High Severity Alert Trends</h2>
<p>We have observed a clear increase in the number of alerts in 2024, correlating with the rise in attacks on cloud environments.</p>
<p>High severity cloud alerts increased by 235% throughout 2024. The largest single-month spike (281%) occurred in May, and we noted the most substantial increase in these alerts (204%, 247% and 122%) in August, October and December, as shown in Figure 1.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138751" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138751" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138751 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-5.png" alt="Line graph showing monthly fluctuation rates by percentage ranging from -100% to 200% with peaks in April, July, October, and December, and troughs in February, June, and September. Palo Alto Networks | UNIT 42 logo lockup at the bottom. " width="1000" height="504" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-5.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-5-786x396.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-5-1389x700.png 1389w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-5-768x387.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-5-1536x774.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138751" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. High severity alert trends for 2024.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138739-_iqzqaej80b"></a>Top 10 High Alerts</h3>
<p>A closer look at the top 10 most frequent daily high severity alerts reveals a high number of alerts pertaining solely to runtime-focused events. These alerts are triggered by a singular event or a sequence of connected events. This necessitated near real-time analysis or, in some instances, real-time analysis for detection.</p>
<p>Table 2 below shows that the remote command-line usage of the serverless IAM tokens is an event that requires real-time log analysis to detect and potentially to prevent. Conversely, the most frequent high severity alert, “cloud storage delete protection disabled,” can be detected and mitigated with a CSPM tool.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Alert Name</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Runtime or Posture Control</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Average Daily Count</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Remote command line usage of serverless token</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">24.68</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">An identity performed a suspicious download of multiple cloud storage objects</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">21.09</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Cloud Storage Delete Protection Disabled</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Posture and Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">20.19</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Abnormal Allocation of compute resources in a high number of regions</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Posture and Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">11.11</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">A Kubernetes node service account was used outside the cluster from non-cloud IP</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Posture</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">11</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Abnormal Suspicious allocation of compute resources in multiple regions</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Posture and Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">10</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Multiple cloud snapshots export</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">9.33</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Remote command line usage of serverless role</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7.79</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Unusual allocation of multiple cloud compute resources</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Posture and Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7.73</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Abnormal Unusual allocation of compute resources in multiple regions</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Posture and Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">6.42</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 2. High severity alerting by average occurrence.</span></p>
<p>To ensure the protection of cloud storage objects within a storage container whose delete protection has been disabled, we highly recommend deploying a CDR tool. These tools can detect and prevent any cloud storage objects from being deleted as a result of a ”protection disabled” event.</p>
<p>Other notable high severity alerts include multiple cloud snapshot exports and suspicious usage of a service account IAM. Both of these are key indicators of malicious activity within a cloud environment.</p>
<p>Examples of malicious operations that could trigger several of these alerts are cloud-focused extortion or ransomware events. These types of events can only be leveraged by first disabling cloud storage protections, such as delete protection and automatic backups. Once these protections are removed, malicious actors can delete or exfiltrate cloud storage container objects, increasing the likelihood of a successful extortion operation.</p>
<p>Some of these high severity alerts could also be triggered by the compromise of exposed or vulnerable serverless or compute instance resources. Specifically in terms of the remote command-line usage of a serverless IAM token, serverless functions are designed to operate autonomously and independently.</p>
<p>Remote or unauthorized usage of a serverless function's IAM token indicates compromise and potential lateral movement within the cloud environment. The same type of event could indicate the malicious usage of a service account IAM token. Given that service account IAM tokens are typically intended for a single purpose, any abnormal usage of that token should be considered suspicious.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138739-_53opwrw6l1n5"></a>Medium Severity Alert Trends</h2>
<p>Unlike the end-of-year high severity alert spike, we saw a sustained spike in medium severity alerts mid-2024. This spike included an initial 186% and subsequent 24% increase, before a downward trend through December, as Figure 2 shows.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138762" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138762" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138762 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-6.png" alt="Line graph showing monthly fluctuation rates by percentage ranging from 0% to 3% with a trough in January through March and rising in April where it peaks in May-June, then falls to slightly lower through the rest of the year. Palo Alto Networks | UNIT 42 logo lockup at the bottom." width="1000" height="509" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-6.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-6-786x400.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-6-1374x700.png 1374w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-6-768x391.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/chart-6-1536x782.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138762" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Medium severity alert trends for 2024.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138739-_dsue6fk0douc"></a>Top 10 Medium Alerts</h3>
<p>The top 10 medium severity alerts, shown in Table 3 below, differ from the top 10 high severity alerts listed in Table 2 above. The key difference is that for all but one of the top 10 medium severity alerts, the events can only be detected by performing some form of runtime protection analytics.</p>
<p>The “unusual high-volume data transfer” event can be triggered using traditional CSPM detections of cloud resources. However, like the high severity “cloud storage delete protection disabled” event discussed above, a CDR tool would be better able to detect this unusual volume transfer event as it was occurring. It could also identify the types of files and their cloud storage file or directory locations. These details provide security teams with the most desired resources to perform their jobs: time, and knowledge.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Alert Name</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Runtime or Posture Control</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Average Daily Count</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">An IAM identity attempted multiple actions on resources that were denied</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">80</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">A compute-attached identity executed API calls outside the instance's region</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">36.32</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Attempted cloud application access from unusual tenant</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">21.69</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">An identity performed a suspicious download of multiple cloud storage objects from multiple buckets</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">18.66</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Impossible travel by a cloud compute identity</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">18.65</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Unusual storage high-volume data transfer</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">15</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Kubernetes service account activity outside the cluster from non-cloud IP</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">12.15</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">A cloud application performed multiple actions that were denied</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">12.02</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Multiple cloud snapshots export</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">10</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Suspicious identity downloaded multiple objects from a backup storage bucket</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Runtime</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">9.68</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 3. Medium severity alerting by average occurrence.</span></p>
<p>Several of the alerts listed in Table 3 could indicate that malicious actors are targeting cloud resources such as Kubernetes service accounts outside of the cluster or from a non-cloud IP address. These two alerts in particular might indicate that the Kubernetes cluster authentication tokens have been compromised, as service account IAM tokens are designed for a singular purpose. Any operation using these credentials from outside of the cluster — or outside of the known cloud environment — should be considered suspicious activity and should be mitigated.</p>
<p>Another alert that is important to highlight is exporting multiple cloud snapshots. While there can be a legitimate use case for this type of event — such as th​​e deployment of snapshots or an external backup — threat actors also export snapshots. Cloud snapshots can contain sensitive information, making them a common target of malicious operations.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138739-_gq6nlvnoa86v"></a>What Organizations Can Do</h2>
<p>There are several steps that organizations can implement to better protect themselves against malicious cloud operations:</p>
<ul>
<li>Implement effective CDR runtime monitoring
<ul>
<li>Deploy a CDR cloud security for all of your cloud environments</li>
<li>Ensure that all mission-critical cloud endpoints have runtime enabled agents to detect compute and container runtime operations</li>
<li>Ensure runtime cloud audit log monitoring is available from your CSP providers</li>
<li>Ensure that your integrated cloud SaaS applications collect:
<ul>
<li>Identity providers (IdP)</li>
<li>CI/CD integrations</li>
<li>Source code repositories</li>
<li>Ticketing platforms</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Place limits on CSP regions in which compute and serverless functions are allowed to operate
<ul>
<li>It is common practice for threat actors to create cloud resources within foreign CSP regions to perform a basic form of operation obfuscation</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Identify and prevent IAM service accounts from performing operations outside of their intended functions
<ul>
<li>Following least-privilege architecture design for IAM credentials can greatly assist in combating lateral movement and privilege escalation operations if an IAM credential is compromised</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Ensure that cloud storage versioning and encryption are in place for all cloud storage containers
<ul>
<li>Versioning and encryption are free configurations for every cloud storage container from each of the three major cloud service providers</li>
<li>These two features also significantly increase the difficulties that threat actors will encounter when trying to steal your valuable, sensitive information</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>If in doubt, remember that CDR runtime monitoring defenses <strong>must</strong> be present to effectively combat the majority of threats faced by cloud environments.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138739-_u1ycaimyxxn6"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>CDR runtime monitoring is a critical aspect of maintaining a secure-cloud, hybrid-cloud and multi-cloud environment. As the trending high and medium severity alert data discussed in this article demonstrate, there was a 388% increase in the average number of alerts that cloud environments witnessed during 2024.</p>
<p>A significant number of these alerts are the direct result of the detection of runtime operations, which cannot be detected with posture management (CSPM) tools alone. CDR tools provide cloud runtime detection capabilities, enabling the detection of malicious events occurring on cloud compute instances, container hosts or serverless functions.</p>
<p>Given the increasing threats targeting cloud environments, the only real defense for these environments is to require cloud-based agents for publicly exposed and critical cloud endpoints, CSP audit logging and cloud third-party SaaS applications. Using a CDR analytics tool allows defenders to collect, detect and prevent the execution of malicious operations that can affect any of these resources. The combination of runtime monitoring, analysis and response for cloud resource event logging is essential to ensure that malicious operations are not allowed to function within cloud environments.</p>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>, or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 00080005045107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138739-_qy9ev41lh1n5"></a>References</h2>

</ul>

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/13_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of vulnerabilities in Vertex AI.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:related-resources:ModeLeak: Privilege Escalation to LLM Model Exfiltration in Vertex AI:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-11-12T11:00:11+00:00">November 12, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/privilege-escalation-llm-model-exfil-vertex-ai/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:related-resources:ModeLeak: Privilege Escalation to LLM Model Exfiltration in Vertex AI">
                    <h4 class="post-title">ModeLeak: Privilege Escalation to LLM Model Exfiltration in Vertex AI</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/data-exfiltration/" title="data exfiltration" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:related-resources:ModeLeak: Privilege Escalation to LLM Model Exfiltration in Vertex AI:data exfiltration">Data exfiltration</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/google-cloud/" title="Google Cloud" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:related-resources:ModeLeak: Privilege Escalation to LLM Model Exfiltration in Vertex AI:Google Cloud">Google Cloud</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/kubernetes/" title="Kubernetes" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:related-resources:ModeLeak: Privilege Escalation to LLM Model Exfiltration in Vertex AI:Kubernetes">Kubernetes</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/privilege-escalation-llm-model-exfil-vertex-ai/" title="ModeLeak: Privilege Escalation to LLM Model Exfiltration in Vertex AI" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:related-resources:ModeLeak: Privilege Escalation to LLM Model Exfiltration in Vertex AI:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/04_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="A pictorial representation of ShinyHunters ransomware.                   <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/openssh/" title="OpenSSH" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="2025-cloud-security-alert-trends:related-resources:Threat Brief: CVE-2024-6387 OpenSSH RegreSSHion Vulnerability:OpenSSH">OpenSSH</a>

				</li>
